conversation.content: [nervous] The appointment confirmation said Officer Martinez would be, [confused], handling Mr. Chen's case but you look so, [trembling], familiar somehow.
[defensive] Well, um, I've been assigned to this district for, [formal], three years now so maybe you've seen me around, you know.
Wait, your voice sounds exactly like my brother's but he, [shocked], disappeared after mom's funeral and changed his, [shaky voice], name and never came back to, [very quietly], any of us.
[stern] I mean, um, we should really focus on, [quickly], your employer's compliance requirements and not get distracted by, well, personal matters.
[emotional] Um, Marcus, I know it's you because, [whispering], you still do that thing with your left hand when you're lying, you know.
[bitter] Even if I was this Marcus person you're talking about, [regretful], what difference would it make after all these years? [sigh]
[crying while speaking] Well, um, Dad searched for you for, [desperate], five years before his heart gave out and I, er, never stopped hoping you'd come home. [pause]
[apologetic] Look, I mean, um, becoming a probation officer was, [slowly], my way of making amends for things I couldn't fix back then, you know.
[angry] So you've been, um, living forty minutes away this whole time helping, [frustrated], strangers rebuild their lives while we thought you were, [loudly], dead or worse, I mean?
[whispering loudly] Please stop.

[warm] I'm not going to lose you again, not when, well, um, the universe literally put you in, [empathetically], my conference room after all these years of wondering if you were even, [relieved], alive. [long pause]
The guilt from that night when mom died and I wasn't, [anxious], there because I was too proud to come home after our fight has been, [exhausted], eating me alive for fifteen, [very sad], years.

[soothing] Um, I mean, none of us blamed you for not being there because, [gently], the accident happened so suddenly that even dad who was, [hesitantly], five minutes away couldn't make it in time, you know.
[upset] Well, er, I blamed myself enough for everyone and, [monotone], changing my name seemed like the only way to, [trailing off], escape from the person who failed her when she needed me most...
[confident] Mom left you a letter that she wrote, [tenderly], two weeks before the accident. [gasp softly]
Um, I mean, after all this time, [curious], what could she possibly have written that would change anything, you know?

[very sincerely] Well, um, she knew about your fight and wrote that, [passionately], she was proud of you for standing up for yourself even against her and that, [cheerful], real love means letting people grow beyond our expectations, you know.
[surprised] Um, she actually wrote that she was, [tearful], proud of me for walking away from her demands about law school, er?

She kept it in her purse planning to mail it but then the, [melancholic], accident happened and dad found it when they returned her, [quietly], belongings and we've kept it sealed all these, [hopeful], years.
[overwhelmed] I mean, um, fifteen years of self-imposed exile because I thought she, [broken], died hating me and now you're telling me she actually, er, understood? [sob]

scenario: A personal assistant discovers their employer's probation officer is actually their estranged sibling who disappeared after a family tragedy fifteen years ago.
